properties.name: Cambridge
properties.description: Posted by ThisismoneyCB2 3AA, EnglandCambridge is lauded as a centre of academic excellence, but it also possesses an unenviable reputation - as home to the post office with the longest queues. The branch in question is the main post office situated on St Andrew\'s Street. Earlier this year, a Postwatch undercover survey labelled it the country\'s worst offender for queues, with a customer waiting time of up to 21 minutes. Unfortunately, nine months on, despite being admonished by Postwatch, the queues do not seem to be shrinking. Last week, when Financial Mail visited, only three of the main 13 counters were open despite it being lunchtime and more than two-dozen people waiting - though customers say it can get far busier. Read the full story Blog: Travels with Toby

properties.name: Chesham Bois
properties.description: Posted by ThisismoneyHP5 1DE, EnglandWalking past the cluster of shops in the attractive village of Chesham Bois, nothing appears amiss. It is a quiet and pleasant spot with a steady stream of customers arriving by car to shop. Yet despite an upmarket feel to the parade in Bois Lane, which includes a home furnishings shop with coffee bar and a butcher\'s shop, there is a lack of grassroots services. Luxury goods and cappuccinos are all well and good, say locals, but there is nowhere for basic groceries, postage or banking needs. Read the full story Blog: Travels with Toby

properties.name: Crewe
properties.description: Posted by ThisismoneyCW1 5EQ, EnglandRoyal Mail launched a competition three months ago to find the country\'s favourite post offices. Embarrassingly, not long after, the Government said its support of the 14,300-strong network was unsustainable and that two-thirds could be axed. Last Thursday, behind closed doors, GMTV presenter Lorraine Kelly and Royal Mail \'unveiled\' the competition winners. Financial Mail on Sunday reporters visited the winning post offices to get reaction from postmasters and postmistresses and their customers. Overall winner: Running a post office is in Alan Green\'s blood. His grandfather, William Green, opened the doors of the family\'s sub-post office in Crewe, Cheshire, almost 50 years ago. And Alan\'s father, Neville, took over in 1977. Thirteen years ago, the post office moved a couple of hundred yards to its current location in Hungerford Road on the town\'s eastern edge. Neville and his wife, Margaret, ran the business until Alan took over ten years ago. Blog: Travels with Toby

properties.name: Galmpton
properties.description: Posted by ThisismoneyTQ5 0NH, EnglandThe quiet Devon village of Galmpton near Brixham is an unlikely setting for a revolution. But it is here that subpostmaster Gary Deare, 47, believes he has discovered a formula to transform the gloomy prospects of many threatened branches - with up to 3,000 facing the axe in the latest cull. Sick of Government meddling, he has embraced the ideas of his local community to create a post office branch that is thriving against the odds. There is nothing to make the old-fashioned Galleon Stores & Galmpton Post Office stand out - other than a fresh lick of white paint. Across the road is a family butcher and a hairdresser, the only other shops that serve this 1,200-strong community on the banks of the River Dart. But step inside and former bank manager Gary has revamped the interior, creating an innovative \'express post office\' service and a shop selling organic produce. Read the full story Blog: Travels with Toby

properties.name: Isle of Wight
properties.description: Posted by ThisismoneyPO31 7BS, EnglandThey are a belligerent bunch on the Isle of Wight. Faced with a Government that seems determined to smash Britain\'s post office network, the islanders have fought back by issuing a \'unilateral declaration of independence\', calling for their post offices to be removed from Royal Mail control. And there is good reason to fight. The island has 52 branches serving 120,000 people, which is one for every 2,308 residents and almost double the national average. But that does not include the 2.6m \'grockles\' - tourists - who holiday on the island every year and often use the post office network. Yet the Government is poised to destroy this thriving network, allowing the closure of 35 branches, leaving only 17 post offices by 2010. Read the full story Blog: Travels with Toby

properties.name: Maesby Marsh
properties.description: Posted by ThisismoneySY10 8JB, EnglandDeep in rural Shropshire along a quiet stretch of canal sits a shiny new post office on the edge of the hamlet of Maesbury Marsh. Opened just three months ago, Canal Central is probably the most modern post office in Britain and one of only a handful opened in recent years. Since the start of the decade, the network of 18,500 post offices has been slashed to barely 12,500. A further 3,000 are expected to close within the next 18 months. Against this gloomy background, subpostmaster Iain Campbell, 45, and his partner Fiona MacDonald, 36, decided that they needed to be radical to boost their hopes of survival. Read the full story Blog: Travels with Toby

properties.name: Moston
properties.description: Posted by ThisismoneyM40 9WJ, EnglandThe shutters are down on several shops in the litter-strewn parade, including the Chain Bar sub-post office, which was axed two years ago as part of the Government\'s \'urban reinvention programme\'. It was closed down despite the fact that Moston in north-east Manchester is home to 20,000 people, many of whom are dependent on state benefits and were regular post office users. As far as the people of Moston are concerned, the programme triggered urban destruction. Baker Nick Cogger, 47, has been in the area for 20 years. He runs Howarth\'s Bakery with his wife Julie, 47. He shakes his head at the terrible state of the area and says: \'We don\'t see many of our customers any more. They drifted away when the post office went.\' Read the full story Blog: Travels with Toby

properties.name: Sheepy Magna
properties.description: Posted by ThisismoneyCV9 3QR, EnglandThree thousand have closed since early 2002, largely as a result of the scrapping of old-style benefits books and an urban closure programme. But this number will pale into insignificance compared with the avalanche of closures in coming years as the Government withdraws its Â£150m annual subsidy to rural branches. And the withdrawal of the Post Office card account, confirmed this month, will also hit hard. The four million people who use the account to obtain cash will be forced to have their benefits paid direct into bank accounts. properties.name: Youlgreave
properties.description: Posted by ThisismoneyDE45 1UR, EnglandThe post office at the heart of Youlgreave village in the glorious Peak District faces a bleak future with the Government\'s decision to axe the Post Office card account. Three years ago, when pensioners and others on benefits were told they could no longer receive payments in cash, hundreds took the Post Office\'s advice and opened a card account, which allows benefits, pensions and tax credits to be collected at post offices using a card and Pin. They thought that doing so secured the future of their post office branch. But now they fear the worst. If the account is scrapped, as the Government has now indicated it will be, pensioners and other benefits recipients will be forced to use their banks, stripping post offices of business and revenue. Read the full story Blog: Travels with Toby
